Introduction

Lysosomal storage diseases are inherited metabolic disorders that occur due to lysosomal enzyme deficiencies.  These deficiencies impair lysosomal metabolism, resulting in the accumulation of various metabolic substrates within the lysosome.  Over time, these substrates cause clinically significant cellular and tissue dysfunction.

Pathophysiology



Lysosomes are cytoplasmic organelles that contain enzymes (ie, acid hydrolases) required for the degradation of various macromolecules (eg, mucopolysaccharides, sphingolipids).  In lysosomal storage diseases, enzyme deficiencies result in impaired metabolism of these macromolecules, allowing them to accumulate within the lysosome.  Over time, accumulation of these substrates results in cellular dysfunction.  Patients are typically asymptomatic at birth but develop symptoms as the substrate accumulates.  The clinical presentations of each lysosomal storage disease vary, but common features include dysmorphic features, hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, neuropathy, abnormal tone, and ataxia.



Lysosomal storage diseases are categorized by the type of substrate that accumulates.  This article will discuss the major categories of lysosomal storage diseases, including mucopolysaccharidoses, sphingolipidoses, and inclusion cell (I-cell) disease.

Mucopolysaccharidoses



Mucopolysaccharidoses are characterized by a deficiency in the enzymes required for the metabolism of mucopolysaccharides, which are long, unbranched polysaccharides attached to a protein core.  They are primarily found in mucus, joint fluid, and the extracellular matrix of certain types of connective tissues (eg, vitreous humor of the eye).  The most common mucopolysaccharidoses include Hurler and Hunter syndromes (

).

Hurler syndrome



Hurler syndrome (type I mucopolysaccharidosis) occurs due to impaired metabolism of dermatan and heparan sulfate.



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Î±-L-iduronidase.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Dermatan and heparan sulfate.


Hurler syndrome is characterized by severe developmental delay and intellectual disability, corneal clouding, and coarse facial features (eg, frontal bossing, broad nose, flat midface).  Hepatosplenomegaly and coronary artery disease (due to deposition of dermatan and heparan sulfate within the vessels) are common.  Death typically occurs in early childhood (age <10) due to cardiac complications (eg, myocardial infarction).

Hunter syndrome



Hunter syndrome (type II mucopolysaccharidosis) occurs due to impaired metabolism of dermatan and heparan sulfate.



  • Inheritance pattern:  X-linked recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Iduronate sulfatase.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Dermatan and heparan sulfate.


Hunter syndrome, the only X-linked mucopolysaccharidosis, is characterized by a milder phenotype than Hurler syndrome.  Clinical features include aggressive behavior but not corneal clouding.  Death typically occurs in adolescence or early adulthood.

Sphingolipidoses



Sphingolipidoses are characterized by deficiencies in the enzymes required for the metabolism of sphingolipids (eg, glycosphingolipids, phosphosphingolipids) (

figure 1
), complex lipids that are essential components of cell membranes.  The most common sphingolipidoses are discussed below (

).

Fabry disease



Fabry disease occurs due to impaired metabolism of globotriaosylceramide (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).



  • Inheritance pattern:  X-linked recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Î±-galactosidase A.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Globotriaosylceramide.


Fabry disease, the only sphingolipidosis that is X-linked, typically presents in childhood and early adolescence with neuropathic pain due to globotriaosylceramide deposition in nerve tissue.  Angiokeratomas and telangiectasias often develop in late adolescence.  Multiorgan involvement occurs in adulthood, and patients are at increased risk for cardiac disease (eg, left ventricular hypertrophy) and cerebrovascular disease (eg, transient ischemic attack, stroke).  In addition, globotriaosylceramide accumulation in the glomerulus and distal renal tubule can cause proteinuria and polyuria, respectively, and can progress to renal failure.

Tay-Sachs disease



Tay-Sachs disease occurs due to impaired metabolism of GM2 ganglioside.



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  êžµ-hexosaminidase A.
  • Accumulated substrate:  GM2 ganglioside.


Patients with Tay-Sachs disease develop normally for the first few months of life because the gradual accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neuronal lysosomes does not initially cause cellular dysfunction.  However, by age 6 months excess GM2 ganglioside leads to loss of previously achieved developmental milestones (eg, no longer able to roll over or sit independently).  Other clinical findings include macrocephaly, seizures, spasticity, and an exaggerated startle reflex.



Ganglioside accumulation occurs in the retina but spares the fovea, which lacks ganglion cells.  As a result, the retina appears opaque, whereas the unaffected fovea remains bright red due to the underlying choroid, leading to the classic fundoscopic finding of a cherry-red spot at the macula (

image 1
).  Patients have poor vision, and progressive neurodegeneration typically leads to death at age 2-5.

Gaucher disease



Gaucher disease occurs due to impaired metabolism of glucocerebroside (

).



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  êžµ-glucocerebrosidase.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Glucocerebroside.


The clinical presentation of Gaucher disease is related to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within the lysosomes of macrophages as they engulf cellular debris.  These lipid-laden macrophages, known as Gaucher cells (

image 2
), have a characteristic wrinkled tissue paper appearance and secrete lysosomal proteases and cytokines that disrupt cellular function.  Patients can present at any age with various clinical manifestations, including:



  • Severe hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Pancytopenia (eg, pallor, fatigue, easy bleeding).
  • Bone pain:  Following bone marrow infiltration, Gaucher cells release lysosomal enzymes and inflammatory mediators that cause bone pain (which is worse at night) and osteopenia that can lead to joint collapse and pathologic fractures.
  • Delayed puberty and poor growth.
  • CNS involvement:  Can lead to spasticity, muscle spasms, and loss of motor skills.

Niemann-Pick disease



Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to impaired metabolism of sphingomyelin.



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Sphingomyelinase.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Sphingomyelin.


Sphingomyelin accumulates in lysosomes, which can be visualized as enlarged, vacuolated cells, often referred to as lipid-laden foam cells (

image 3
).  Foam cells accumulate in the liver, spleen, and CNS, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and progressive neurologic symptoms (eg, hypotonia, absent reflexes, neurodegeneration).



After a period of normal development in early infancy, patients lose previously achieved developmental milestones (eg, no longer able to roll over or sit independently).  In addition, sphingomyelin accumulation in the retinal ganglion cells leads to retinal opacification, which gives the appearance of a cherry-red macula.  Niemann-Pick disease is progressive, and death usually occurs by age 3.

Krabbe disease



Krabbe disease occurs due to impaired metabolism of galactolipids formed during white matter myelination.



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Galactocerebrosidase.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Galactocerebroside and psychosine (galactosylsphingosine).


Krabbe disease is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, peripheral neuropathy, and optic nerve atrophy due to loss of myelin.  Optic nerve atrophy can be visualized as optic nerve pallor on fundoscopic examination.  The disease typically presents in infancy, and death often occurs by age 2.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy



Metachromatic leukodystrophy occurs due to impaired metabolism of cerebroside sulfate.



  • Inheritance pattern:  Autosomal recessive.
  • Deficiency:  Arylsulfatase A.
  • Accumulated substrate:  Cerebroside sulfate.


The clinical presentation of metachromatic leukodystrophy is central and peripheral nervous system demyelination, leading to neurologic regression, seizures, and ataxia.

Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease



Unlike mucopolysaccharidoses and sphingolipidoses, each of which occurs due to a specific acid hydrolase enzyme deficiency, I-cell disease involves deficiencies of multiple lysosomal enzymes.  In I-cell disease, acid hydrolase enzymes are transported to the extracellular space, rather than the lysosomes.  Normally, acid hydrolase enzymes undergo posttranslational modification in the Golgi apparatus, including phosphorylation of mannose residues by a phosphotransferase enzyme.  This mannose-6-phosphate tag marks the enzyme for transport to the lysosome.  In I-cell disease, a defect in the phosphotransferase enzyme results in enzyme transfer to the extracellular space, and various substrates accumulate in the lysosomes, forming the characteristic inclusion bodies.



I-cell disease demonstrates an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, and the clinical presentation includes failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory tract infections, and cognitive deficits in the first year of life, along with characteristic physical features (eg, coarse facies, corneal clouding, hepatosplenomegaly).

Diagnosis



Diagnosis involves a thorough history (including birth history and family history) and physical examination.  Certain conditions are associated with specific histologic features, and further evaluation depends on the suspected disease.  Enzyme assays may be necessary to measure enzyme activity in leukocytes or fibroblasts.  Genetic testing is often performed to identify the underlying mutation.

Management and prognosis



In general, the prognosis for lysosomal storage disease is poor, with death occurring in childhood or adolescents for most patients.  Management is generally supportive (eg, physical therapy, vision/hearing support), but enzyme replacement therapy is available for patients with Gaucher disease, Fabry disease, Hurler syndrome, and Hunter syndrome.  These therapies improve symptoms and slow progression, leading to a more favorable prognosis.  Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may prevent disease progression in some conditions.

Summary



Lysosomal storage diseases are inherited metabolic disorders that occur due to lysosomal enzyme deficiencies, resulting in the accumulation of various metabolic substrates within the lysosome.  Clinical presentation varies, but common features include dysmorphic features, hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and ataxia.  Prognosis is poor overall, and management involves supportive care.  Enzyme replacement therapies are available for certain diseases.
